verses.text: The second lot came out for Simeon, for the tribe of the descendants of Simeon according to their clans. Their inheritance was inside the territory of Judah.
verses.comment: Simeon’s inheritance being within Judah fulfills God’s prophecy regarding their dispersion (Genesis 49:5-7). It also highlights the concept of unity through diversity within God’s people, a principle seen in the closely connected life of the early Church.

verses.text: Their inheritance included Beersheba, Sheba, Moladah,
verses.comment: Beersheba has historic significance as a place of covenant. Covenantal faith is a theme carried throughout Scripture, pointing to the ultimate New Covenant established by Christ.

verses.text: Hazar-shual, Balah, Ezem,
verses.comment: The inclusion of these cities demonstrates God’s precision in fulfilling His promises. Each territory matters in God's providence, hinting at the spiritual inheritance now available in Christ (Ephesians 1:11).

verses.text: Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah,
verses.comment: Places named recall past victories and failures, showing how redemption and restoration are part of God's plan.

verses.text: Ziklag, Beth-markaboth, Hazar-susah,
verses.comment: Ziklag later becomes significant in David’s life. Biblical history reveals continuity, showing both the physical and spiritual journey towards the establishment of God’s Kingdom.

verses.text: Beth-lebaoth, and Sharuhen—thirteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Thirteen cities emphasize the thoroughness of God’s gift to Simeon. God’s generosity in providing for His people foreshadows the richness of spiritual blessings in Christ.

verses.text: Ain, Rimmon, Ether, and Ashan—four cities with their villages.
verses.comment: This verse shows careful organization and stewardship, reflecting the ordered structure seen in God’s household (1 Timothy 3:15).

verses.text: And all the villages that were around these cities as far as Baalath-beer, Ramah of the Negeb. This was the inheritance of the tribe of the descendants of Simeon according to their clans.
verses.comment: God’s provision for Simeon is both material and communal. This sense of shared inheritance reflects the communion of believers united in faith.

verses.text: The inheritance of the descendants of Simeon was taken from the portion of the descendants of Judah, for the portion of the descendants of Judah was too large for them. So the descendants of Simeon received an inheritance within Judah’s inheritance.
verses.comment: Judah’s generosity in sharing highlights brotherly love and self-sacrifice, foundational virtues for the Church community living as one body.

verses.text: The third lot came up for Zebulun according to their clans. The territory of their inheritance stretched up to Sarid.
verses.comment: Zebulun’s inheritance fulfills prophecy and further affirms the reliability of God’s promises. Prophecy finds deeper meaning as it points to the Messiah’s coming.

verses.text: Their border went up westward to Maralah, reached Dabbesheth, and extended to the brook that is east of Jokneam.
verses.comment: Borders mark out the physical land but also symbolize the boundaries of God’s providential care. The concept of “territory” subtly refers to sacred space, anticipating themes of holiness and consecration.

verses.text: From Sarid it turned east toward the sunrise to the border of Chisloth-tabor, then went out to Daberath, and up to Japhia.
verses.comment: The eastward direction is often associated with new beginnings and spiritual enlightenment (Genesis 2:8, Matthew 24:27).

verses.text: From there it passed eastward to Gath-hepher, to Eth-kazin, then went out to Rimmon and turned to Neah.
verses.comment: Gath-hepher is known as the hometown of the prophet Jonah, showing how ordinary places can feature in God’s extraordinary plans.

verses.text: On the north, the border turned toward Hannathon, and ended at the Valley of Iphtahel.
verses.comment: The precise boundaries emphasize order and intentionality—orderliness is a mark of God’s work both in the world and in the Church.

verses.text: Included were Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem—twelve cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Bethlehem foreshadows its importance as the birthplace of Christ (Micah 5:2; Matthew 2:1), integrating Old and New Testament prophecy.

verses.text: This was the inheritance of the descendants of Zebulun according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Zebulun’s territory and villages further display God’s care for every detail. The ordered inheritance prefigures the fullness of life in the Kingdom.

verses.text: The fourth lot came out for Issachar, for the descendants of Issachar according to their clans.
verses.comment: Issachar’s portion marks another fulfillment of Israel’s tribal identity, each part forming the greater whole of God’s people.

verses.text: Their territory included Jezreel, Chesulloth, Shunem,
verses.comment: Jezreel and Shunem become sites of future miraculous works; the land sets the stage for God’s continuing revelation.

verses.text: Hapharaim, Shion, and Anaharath,
verses.comment: Less prominent sites also play a role, illustrating that all members of God's people, even those seemingly minor, are significant in the plan of redemption.

verses.text: Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
verses.comment: The listing of cities encourages reflection on the diversity and unity of the Church, echoing Paul’s teaching on the body of Christ.

verses.text: Remeth, En-gannim, En-haddah, and Beth-pazzez.
verses.comment: En-gannim means “spring of gardens,” alluding to the life-giving waters and fruitful abundance found in God’s presence.

verses.text: The boundary reached Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth-shemesh, ending at the Jordan—sixteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Beth-shemesh, a site of priestly ministry, highlights the importance of holy service and the role of ordained leadership in the community.

verses.text: This was the inheritance of the tribe of the descendants of Issachar according to their clans, the cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Issachar’s inheritance is another instance of collective participation, drawing all believers into a shared communion.

verses.text: The fifth lot came out for the tribe of the descendants of Asher according to their clans.
verses.comment: Asher’s lot resonates with Jacob’s prophecy about abundance and blessing, underscoring God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: Their territory included Helkath, Hali, Beten, Achshaph,
verses.comment: These sites recount places of influence and cultural exchange. The Church would later be called to spread across nations, emphasizing universality.

verses.text: Allammelech, Amad, and Mishal. It reached west to Carmel and Shihor-libnath.
verses.comment: Carmel is associated with prophetic ministry. The westward reach hints at mission and expansion—key features of the Church’s growth.

verses.text: Then it turned east to Beth-dagon and reached Zebulun and the Valley of Iphtahel northward to Beth-emek and Neiel. Then it extended north to Cabul.
verses.comment: Beth-dagon may relate to pagan worship, yet God’s people are set apart for holiness, transforming culture from within.

verses.text: Ebron, Rehob, Hammon, and Kanah, as far as Great Sidon.
verses.comment: Sidon’s mention anticipates later interactions with Gentiles, pointing forward to the inclusion of all nations in salvation history (Acts 10:34-35).

verses.text: Then the border turned back to Ramah, as far as the fortified city of Tyre. Then the border turned to Hosah and ended at the sea—Mahalab, Achzib.
verses.comment: Tyre later becomes a metaphor for spiritual riches and God’s judgment. The sea boundary foreshadows the Church’s universal mission reaching to all peoples.

verses.text: Ummah, Aphek, and Rehob—twenty-two cities with their villages.
verses.comment: The completeness of the list displays God’s attention to detail and the abundance of His provision.

verses.text: This was the inheritance of the tribe of the descendants of Asher according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Asher’s inheritance is closely tied to themes of blessedness and unity, which are key marks of the Christian community formed by the Spirit.

verses.text: The sixth lot came out for the descendants of Naphtali, for the tribe of the descendants of Naphtali according to their clans.
verses.comment: Naphtali's inheritance begins fulfillment of prophecies concerning future glory and restoration (Isaiah 9:1–2; Matthew 4:13-16).

verses.text: Their border ran from Heleph, from the oak in Zaanannim, Adami-nekeb, and Jabneel as far as Lakkum and ended at the Jordan.
verses.comment: The Jordan River is a significant biblical boundary, later the place of Christ’s baptism.

verses.text: The border turned westward to Aznoth-tabor and went out from there to Hukkok. It touched Zebulun in the south, Asher on the west, and Judah at the Jordan on the east.
verses.comment: Naphtali’s territory bordered several tribes, signifying interconnectedness in God’s people, a principle foundational for Christian unity.

verses.text: The fortified cities were Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Chinnereth,
verses.comment: Chinnereth (Sea of Galilee) becomes one of the main sites of Christ’s ministry, linking Old Testament land with New Testament fulfillment.

verses.text: Adam, Ramah, Hazor,
verses.comment: Hazor was once a great Canaanite city, illustrating how God’s purposes supersede earthly powers.

verses.text: Kedesh, Edrei, En-hazor,
verses.comment: Kedesh becomes a city of refuge, showing God’s provision for mercy and safety—prefiguring the Church as a spiritual refuge.

verses.text: Iron, Migdal-el, Horem, Beth-anath, and Beth-shemesh—nineteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Migdal-el means 'tower of God,' a symbol for the protection and authority found in God’s household.

verses.text: This was the inheritance of the tribe of the descendants of Naphtali according to their clans, the cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Naphtali's inheritance sets the stage for fulfillment of messianic prophecy in Galilee, where Christ ministered (Matthew 4:15–16).

verses.text: The seventh lot came out for the tribe of the descendants of Dan according to their clans.
verses.comment: Dan’s territory is the last allotted, reminding that all are included in God’s divine order, from first to last.

verses.text: Their territory included Zorah, Eshtaol, Ir-shemesh,
verses.comment: Zorah and Eshtaol become central in the story of Samson, showing God works in every tribe and location.

verses.text: Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Ithlah,
verses.comment: These cities would factor into later Israelite struggles, showing the ongoing drama of salvation history.

verses.text: Elon, Timnah, Ekron,
verses.comment: Timnah and Ekron reference Philistine opposition, setting up key themes of struggle and deliverance in Judges.

verses.text: Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Baalath,
verses.comment: Baalath carries echoes of Israel’s struggle with idolatry, teaching reliance on God’s covenant and faithfulness.

verses.text: Jehud, Bene-berak, Gath-rimmon,
verses.comment: Gath-rimmon later serves as a Levitical city, emphasizing the role of sacred ministry and priestly service among God’s people.

verses.text: and Me-jarkon and Rakkon, with the territory facing Joppa.
verses.comment: Joppa becomes an important port in future biblical events (Acts 10:9–16: Peter’s vision), symbolizing openness to all nations.

verses.text: When the territory of the descendants of Dan was lost to them, they went up and fought against Leshem, captured it, struck it with the sword, took possession of it, and settled there. They called Leshem Dan after the name of their forefather Dan.
verses.comment: Dan’s migration shows flexibility but also tragic compromise, warning against the loss of spiritual inheritance. Yet it also demonstrates zeal for restoration.

verses.text: This was the inheritance of the tribe of the descendants of Dan according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
verses.comment: The Danites’ inheritance closes the tribal allotments, a sign of the fullness and completion of Israel’s earthly pilgrimage.

verses.text: When they finished distributing the land for inheritance by its borders, the Israelites gave Joshua son of Nun an inheritance among them.
verses.comment: Joshua, as leader, receives his portion last, highlighting humility and self-sacrifice. This prefigures Christ, who empties Himself for others (Philippians 2:7).

verses.text: By the command of the LORD, they gave him the city he requested—Timnath-serah in the hill country of Ephraim. He rebuilt the city and settled there.
verses.comment: Joshua’s inheritance received through divine command shows both leader’s service and God’s reward. Rebuilding the city signifies restoration—from ruins to life, just as Christ renews all things.

verses.text: These are the inheritances that Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the heads of the families distributed by lot at Shiloh before the LORD, at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting. So they finished dividing the land.
verses.comment: The distribution at Shiloh, before the Tent of Meeting and under priestly leadership, affirms the importance of sacramental mediation and liturgical worship as part of God’s ordered community. Shiloh later hints at prophecy (Genesis 49:10) fulfilled in Christ, who brings unity, worship, and spiritual inheritance to believers.
